Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Morphological integration between the face and dentition throughout ontogeny

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Differences in the size and shape of the face and teeth are often used to determine the relatedness of species. Modern humans, for example, have flatter faces, wider mouths and smaller teeth compared to chimpanzees and our early human ancestors. What is not fully understood is whether the face and teeth are two separate units that can evolve independently or if they are tightly correlated during evolution. In this project, the investigators will study morphological (shape) integration between the face and teeth in humans, chimpanzees and bonobos to test whether specific changes in the size and shape of the face during growth are associated with particular dental developmental events, such as the formation or eruption of the adult molars. The findings from this project will contribute to our understanding of the evolutionary history of humans, and data will be made available for other studies. The results are more broadly applicable for the planning of orthodontic treatments and craniofacial surgeries, and the project will also support minority undergraduate and graduate training.

During this two-year project, the investigators will use medical computed tomography (CT) and high resolution microCT scans to generate three dimensional (3D) virtual models of the crania and teeth of over 400 humans, chimpanzees and bonobos from existing skeletal collections. Data will be quantified with 3D landmarks and linear, angular and volumetric measurements, and then binned into five grades of dental development to address specific hypotheses about covariation of the face and dentition. The findings will be relevant to primate systematics, craniodental evolution and ontogeny, and may have clinical implications for understanding craniofacial disorders. The microCT and CT data generated by this project will be compiled into an open-access database for other scientific research, thereby increasing virtual access to museum specimens and preventing further damage to fragile skeletal collections. The project will also promote diversity in biological anthropology, as the co-PI is a female, minority graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The size and shape of the crania and teeth have changed throughout human evolution. Modern humans have flatter, less projecting faces, wider jaws, and smaller teeth compared to chimpanzees and our early human ancestors. The teeth and parts of the crania are durable, and abundant in the fossil record. Thus, these elements are used in biological anthropology to identify and determine relatedness among species. A number of hypotheses about the evolution of the face are based on the fact that these regions are tightly associated such that changes in the dentition will produce correlated changes in the face. It has been hypothesized that the flatter face of a fossil human ancestor, Ardipithecus, is related to its relatively smaller front teeth, or the longer and broader face of Paranthropus, another fossil species, has been proposed to be related to its relatively small front teeth and large molars. These hypotheses assume that the traits of the teeth and face are correlated, and therefore not independent, but it is unknown if the face and teeth evolve independently or in coordination. The coordinated covariation between two parts or modules is called morphological integration. The dentition and facial bones have similar developmental origins, functions and the teeth develop in the maxillary bone, which makes it likely that the face and teeth develop in a coordinated manner throughout the growth and development of an organism. This project studied the relationship between the face and teeth throughout the growth and development (ontogeny) of humans and chimpanzees to test if specific changes in the size and shape of the face during growth are associated with particular developmental events, such as molar eruption. The objectives of this project were to analyze the coordinated covariation of traits of the upper jaw and teeth (the pattern of integration), assess how the strength or magnitude of the trait covariation changed across development, and determine if the pattern and magnitude of integration were different between species.

One of the major findings of this research project is that the lower face and permanent teeth of humans and chimpanzees are integrated throughout ontogeny. Thus, the face and permanent teeth likely evolved in coordination through evolution. Humans and chimpanzees have similar patterns of integration between the lower face and the teeth in which individuals with relatively more projecting lower faces, and taller and longer upper jaws have more protruding front teeth. Individuals with relatively broader faces, shorter upper jaws, and flatter lower faces have more retracted, smaller and shorter front teeth. In addition, with increased age and dental development, the face expanded and became more projecting in humans and chimpanzees. The similar patterns of integration in humans and chimpanzees indicate that the relationship between the lower face and teeth has been conserved throughout evolution. The flatter faces that are seen in fossil ancestors may have evolved with smaller front teeth

The change in magnitude of integration throughout ontogeny is another major outcome of this project. The magnitude of integration between two anatomical regions determines if a change in one region produces a change in another region. Several studies have indicated that integration may decline with increasing age, while other studies report that integration increases with age. In this study, both chimpanzees and humans had similar magnitudes of integration that were relatively high in young individuals and in adults. Integration declined during the eruption of first and second molars and then increased in adults to a magnitude similar to the youngest analyzed individuals whom have primary (baby) teeth. Changes in integration and covariance structure over ontogeny may be related to sexual maturity and the extended growth of the face compared to the growth of the braincase. These changes in covariance facilitate increased variation and the creation of new morphological forms.

This project has supported the dissertation work of a minority woman and has provided training opportunities for seven undergraduate students interested in anthropology and the health sciences. Four of these students were women and two of the seven students were underrepresented students. The students received training in human and chimpanzee cranial anatomy, digital imaging techniques, interpretation of cranial CT scans, and three dimensional model creation. The majority of the students are currently pursuing careers in the health sciences, such as radiology, imaging technology, nuclear physics, or medicine. This project has also generated a large dataset of computed tomography (CT) scans that will be used for additional student projects, collaborations and available to other researchers.
